attributes.title: The neural correlates of perception and mental imagery of beauty
attributes.description: Master Thesis studying the cortical activation during perception and mental imagery of artworks and faces with varying degrees of beauty by the means of functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS).

q1.value: The neural correlates of perception and mental imagery of beauty: A fNIRS study

q3.value:
Beauty is something primarily experienced through our senses, be it visual, auditory or tactile. However, Kant (2004) already assumed that experiencing beauty through sensual stimulation requires subsequent thoughts. This old assumption has been confirmed by Brielmann and Pelli (2017). They showed that when thought processes about an aesthetically pleasing object are impaired by a distraction task, we find it less beautiful. These findings suggest that there must be some subsequent neural processes about the perceived object in our brain resulting in an aesthetic experience. One possible mechanism for this would be a mental image lingering in our mind after perceiving an object. 
Generally, visual imagery can be defined as the ability to visualize objects in the absence of retinal stimulation (Marks, 1973). Previous studies have shown that visually imagining an object shows similar neural correlates as actually perceiving that object (Dijkstra, Bosch, & van Gerven, 2017; Ganis, Thompson, & Kosslyn, 2004; Lee, Kravitz, & Baker, 2012)Yet, it has not been tested which role the aesthetic value of the perceived object has on these processes. In this study, we want to address this question. We will investigate, whether it exists a functional equivalence between visual perception and visual imagery and whether this equivalence is modulated by beauty.

q4.value:
Main hypotheses:
1. There is a difference in brain activation in the regions of interest (ROIs) during the perception of beautiful and ugly stimuli. (non-directional)
2. There is a difference in brain activation in the ROIs during the imagination of beautiful and ugly stimuli. (non-directional)
3. There is no difference in brain activation between the two stimuli categories artworks and faces. (non-directional)
4. There is a correlation in brain activation in the ROIs during the mental imagination in the cued imagery task and the free imagery task. (non-directional)

Side hypotheses:
5. Ratings in the vividness of mental imagery correlate with brain activation in the ROI during mental imagery. (non-directional)
6. The extreme ends of the beauty ratings are associated with higher vividness ratings. (directional)

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The study will consist of two parts: the free imagination and the cued imagination task.
The design for the free imagination task will include the two within-subject factors stimuli type (faces/paintings) and degree of beauty (beautiful/ugly) with 2 levels each.
The design for the cued imagination task will include the three within-subject factors stimuli type (faces/paintings), degree of beauty (beautfiul/ugly) and task (perception/imagery) with 2 levels each. The used procedure for this part will be mainly based on the study of Köchel et al. (2011), with slight adjustments.

The two tasks will always be in the same order with the free imagination task first, followed by the cued imagination task.
This is important since we want to avoid that the stimuli of the cued imagination task bias the free imagination task.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
The participants are going to be psychology students, recruited through the LABS-System of the University of Vienna. The LABS-System is an online platform for recruitment purposes. When attending seminars psychology students have to take part in studies for which they get LABS-credits in return. Participants to this study will receive 6 credits (1 credit = 15 minutes)
Participants must be between 18 and 40 years old and have to be capable of giving their consent to study participation themselves.
An exclusion criterion is a strongly impaired vision (V = 0.5 or more) and red-green color blindness due to the requirement to rate a visual experience.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 30 participants. Since in most studies, there is a drop-out rate of 10% we will attempt to recruit 33 participants to get a final sample of 30 participants.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis with the software program G*Power. We specified a power of .80 to detect a medium effect size (Cohens dz= 0.5) at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

question.value:
We manipulated the level of beauty for each stimulus. 
To do this, we selected the stimuli, consisting of faces and paintings, from two different databases which provided beauty ratings. The faces are from the study of Schacht, Werheid, & Sommer, W. (2008) and the paintings are from the JenAesthetics Database. We selected 6 pictures with extremely high or low beauty ratings for both faces and paintings, resulting in 24 stimuli. The faces were matched according to gender and the artworks according to content and depicted colors.

1. As an outcome variable, we will measure brain activity during perception and mental imagery by the means of the functional Near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS). Our regions of Interest (ROI) are the primary visual cortex, the orbitofrontal cortex, and the right dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
2. In the free imagination task, we will measure what participants had imagined in the form of an open question ("Briefly describe what you just imagined").
3. In the cued imagination task, we will ask participants to rate perceived beauty for each stimulus by asking participants "How beautiful do you find this artwork?" (5-point-Likert scale (from 1. ugly to 5. beautiful). 
4. Additionally, we will measure the vividness of the visual image for each stimulus by asking participants "How vivid was your visual image?" on a 5-point-Likert scale (from 1. not vivid at all to 5. completely vivid as if I would see it).
5. We will also measure people’s ability to vividly imagine scenes and objects based on self-report via the Vividness of visual imagery questionnaire (VVIQ).  
6. In addition, participants will fill out one part of the Vienna Art Interest and Art Knowledge Questionnaire (VAIAK), which measures Art Interest (Specker et. al, 2018).
7. We will also collect the following demographic data: sex, age, and highest education degree.
8. We will measure visual acuity and whether the participant has red-green color blindness before the experiment.

Channels covering a specific area (primary visual cortex, orbitofrontal cortex, and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex) will be averaged to get a more accurate estimation of the brain activity in that region. 
The description of what they imagined was measured in the form of an open question and will be coded with a category system. The category system will be developed by means of the data itself.
The 16-item scale of the VVIQ will be summarized in a vividness score between 1 and 4 for each participant, where a score of 1 indicates high and 4 indicates low vividness.
The 12-item Art Interest scale of the VAIAK will be summarized into a sum score, where high values indicate strong Art interest and low values weak Art Interest.

To test the main hypotheses 1, 2 and 3 we will use a 3×2×2 repeated measure analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the factors POSITION (dorsolateral prefrontal cortex/orbitofrontal cortex/primary visual cortex) BEAUTY (ugly/beautiful) and STIMULI (faces/artworks).

To test the main hypothesis 4, we will calculate a Pearson correlation between the free mental imagery task and the cued mental imagery task for each ROI. If the requirement of a normal distribution is violated we will resort to a Spearman correlation.

To test hypothesis 5, a Pearson correlation will be used with the variable vividness ratings for each brain region separately. If the requirement of a normal distribution is violated we will resort to a Spearman correlation.

To test hypothesis 6 we will use a quadratic regression with the two variables ratings in beauty and ratings in vividness. 

To take account of multiple testing, all statistical inferences will be based on a Bonferroni adjusted alpha.

q21.value:
We will use the standard p< .05 criteria to detect whether the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will adjust the p-value for multiple comparisons with a Bonferroni correction.
For all the hypotheses (except hypothesis 6, we will use a two-tailed test.

q22.value:
All fNIRS channels with a coefficient of variation of > 15% and a gain setting of > 8 will be excluded from the analysis.
Also, participants with visual acuity worse than V 0,5 on the eye examination and participants with red-green color blindness (more than two cards of the false) will be excluded.
We will use the Grubb's outlier test to detect outliers. These will then be excluded from the analysis.
We will not use any awareness check since there is no blinding involved in this study.

q23.value:
As stated above, if a channel has a coefficient of variation of > 15% and a gain setting of > 8  the data will be excluded in the analysis.
Missing or incomplete data will also be excluded from the analysis.

q24.value:
As an exploratory analysis, we will look for relationships between art interest and the perception and mental imagination of the artworks. In addition, we will look for relationships between art interest and vividness ratings for the artworks.
Certain demographic traits may be related to the ability to mentally imagine things. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (age, gender) and the primary outcome measures.
As an exploratory analysis, we also want to further investigate the open answers, where participants described their mental image in the free imagery task.

q1.value: Eksperyment Milgrama. Wpływ wzrokowej i słuchowej informacji sensorycznej na uleganie autorytetowi.

q3.value:
To badanie ma być replikacją słynnego eksperymentu Milgrama (1963), który chciał sprawdzić w jakim stopniu posłuszni potrafią być ludzie w określonym kontekście - kiedy polecenia wydaje im osoba autorytarna (w przypadku oryginalnego eksperymentu był to naukowiec, przebrany w biały kitel). W swojej replikacji chciałbym jednak wprowadzić pewne zmiany i rozszerzyć ten eksperyment o dwa dodatkowe warunki. 

W oryginalnym eksperymencie, osoby badane dostały informację, że są dzielone na uczniów i nauczyciel (o przydzielonej roli decydowało losowanie). Osoba badana wchodziła jednak zawsze w rolę nauczyciela (losowała spośród samych losów “nauczyciel”) i była wprowadzana w błąd myśląc, że uczniem będzie inna osoba badana. Tak naprawdę w rolę ucznia, który był umieszczany w innym pomieszczeniu, wcielał się pomocnik eksperymentatora, świadomy manipulacji eksperymentalnej oraz prawdziwej intencji badania. Uczeń był dodatkowo rzekomo podpięty pod aparaturę, przez którą nauczyciel mógł aplikować mu wstrząsy elektryczne o różnej mocy (moc mogła być wybrana na urządzeniu, które symulowało generator prądu, przez użycie odpowiedniego przełącznika gdzie każdy kolejny generował prąd większy o 15V) w zależności od tego, czy odpowiedź ucznia była prawidłowa czy nie. Badany nie widział osoby, której “wymierza karę”, a jedynie słyszał nagrane i zestandaryzowane odpowiedzi werbalne (krzyk, prośby o wypuszczenie). Dodatkowo w pokoju badanego znajdowała się osoba wydająca polecenia. Był to jeden z eksperymentatorów przebrany w biały kitel, odgrywający rolę naukowca. Kiedy osoby badane nie chciały kontynuować eksperymentu eksperymentator ten przekonywał je, by kontynuowały.

Zmiany, które chciałbym wprowadzić w mojej replikacji badania miałyby polegać na tym, by osoby badane były przydzielane do 3 grup (każda grupa odpowiada jednemu warunkowi eksperymentalnemu):

1) Badani słyszą osobę, która jest “karana” 
2) Badani widzą osobę, która jest “karana”
3) Badani widzą i słyszą osobę, która jest “karana”

Celem tego eksperymentu będzie sprawdzenie czy w przypadku warunków drugiego i trzeciego, mniej osób wykona całą procedurę badawczą (tj. dojdzie do siły wstrząsu większej niż 435 V, która byłaby śmiertelna dla ucznia); czy średnia siła wstrząsu, na której badany zatrzyma procedurę badawczą, będzie różna w zależności od warunku eksperymentalnego oraz czy wyniki mojej replikacji będą zbliżone do wyników oryginalnego eksperymentu, pod kątem proporcji ludzi, którzy wykonali całą procedurę badawczą (65%).

q4.value:
Hipoteza 1: Średnia siła wstrząsu mierzona w woltach (V) będzie mniejsza w przypadku grup eksperymentalnych, które zostaną poddane warunkowi 2 lub 3, niż w przypadku warunku 1.

Hipoteza 2: Średnia siła wstrząsu mierzona w woltach (V) będzie najmniejsza w przypadku grupy eksperymentalnej poddanej warunkowi 3.


Hipoteza 3: Procent osób, które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w przypadku warunku eksperymentalnego nr 1 będzie zbliżona do wyniku z oryginalnego badania Milgrama (1963) z odchyleniem na poziomie 5%. 

Hipoteza 4: Procent osób, które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w przypadku warunków eksperymentalnych nr 2 i 3 będzie mniejszy niż procent osób, które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w przypadku warunku eksperymentalnego nr 1.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value:
W przypadku tego badania, osoby badane nie będą wiedziały do której z grup zostaną przydzielone (jedna grupa odpowiada jednemu warunkowi eksperymentalnemu). Ale przede wszystkim nie będą wiedziały jaki jest prawdziwy cel eksperymentu. 

Nie będą również świadome tego, że generator, którym będą mogli aplikować wstrząsy elektryczne jest generatorem symulowanym oraz tego, że tak naprawdę osoba karana nie jest wystawiona na wstrząsy elektryczne.

W samym ogłoszeniu będzie widniała informacja iż jest to badanie na temat "zwiększenia efektywności nauki słówek w języku obcym". Kiedy badany stawi się już na miejscu, zostaje mu przedstawiona następująca informacja:

"Jednym ze sposobów na zwiększenie efektywności uczenia się słówek w języku obcym jest wymierzanie kar. Ale wiemy o tym bardzo mało.

Nie wiemy jaki stopień kary jest najlepszy dla zwiększenia efektywności uczenia się. Nie wiemy też, czy jest różnica kto wymierza karę - osoba młodsza, czy starsza. 

Do tego badania zapraszamy osoby dorosłe o różnym wieku i zawodzie i prosimy ich, by przyjęli rolę nauczyciela lub ucznia. 

Chcielibyśmy dowiedzieć się jaki efekt miałaby kara na uczenie się w takiej sytuacji. DLatego poproszę, by któryś z Państwa przyjął dzisiaj rolę nauczyciela lub ucznia. "

question.value:
Schemat międzygrupowy wieloczynnikowy. Z dwoma czynnikami: 

1. Widzenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara. Ma dwa poziomy: widzi, nie widzi.

2. Słyszenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara”. Ma dwa poziomy: słyszy, nie słyszy.

q9.value: Randomizacja na poziomie dobierania badanych do grup, z zachowaniem zbliżonej średniej wieku we wszystkich trzech grupach eksperymentalnych.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Badani będą rekrutowani przez ogłoszenia na grupach facebookowych, co pozwoli dotrzeć do osób z konkretnej grupy wiekowej oraz na portalach ogłoszeniowych (OLX, GumTree).

Każdy uczestnik za udział w badaniu dostanie 50 zł, niezależnie od tego, czy dokończy procedurę badawczą, czy nie (tak by chęć zdobycia pieniędzy nie była czynnikiem zakłócającym). 

Badanie będzie opisane w ogłoszeniu tak jakby dotyczyło sposobów na zwiększenie efektywności nauki słówek w języku obcym. 

Minimalny wiek uczestników to 18 lat. Uczestnicy nie mogą cierpieć na zaburzenia lękowe, depresję, czy inne ciężkie zaburzenia psychiczne. Wykluczani będą również uczestnicy z wadą wzroku i/lub słuchu, chyba że wady te będą skorygowane za pomocą okularów lub aparatu słuchowego. 

Populacja, do której będą kierowane ogłoszenia o badaniu to mieszkańcy Krakowa, w wieku 20 - 50 lat.

Osoby studiujące kognitywistykę, psychologię i kierunki pokrewne nie będą mogły uczestniczyć w badaniu. Studenci takich kierunków mogą znać oryginalne badanie Milgrama, więc badanie ich byłoby bezużyteczne. 

Zgłoszenie do badania będzie odbywało się przez wypełnienie formularza, gdzie osoby zostaną poproszone o podanie podstawowych informacji o sobie, czyli m.in.: wiek, wywiad medyczny pod kątem chorób psychicznych oraz zaburzeń narządów zmysłów, imię i nazwisko.

q14.value: Taka grupa osób pozwoli na uzyskanie miarodajnych wyników, a jednocześnie nie będzie zbyt trudna do pozyskania.

question.value:
Zmienne, które będą podlegały manipulacji to: 

1) Widzenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara. Ma dwa poziomy: widzi, nie widzi.


2) Słyszenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara”. Ma dwa poziomy: słyszy, nie słyszy.

Zmienna A: Proporcja osób (wyrażona w procentach), które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w poszczególnych warunkach eksperymentalnych.

Zmienna B: Średnia siła wstrząsu, na której badani zakończyli procedurę eksperymentalną, w danej grupie eksperymentalnej wyrażona w woltach (V).
Brak.
Wykorzystam wieloczynnikową ANOVĘ międzygrupową. W celu identyfikacji tego, które grupy istotnie statystycznie  różnią się między sobą zostanie przeprowadzony test post-hoc.

q22.value: Wykluczone zostaną jedynie dane dotyczące osób badanych, które nie będą chciały rozpocząć procedury badawczej (zaaplikować wstrząsu elektrycznego o najmniejszej sile = 15V).

q23.value: Nawet jeśli procedura badawcza nie zostanie dokończona przez osobę badaną, jej dane będą brane pod uwagę przy analizie.

q25.value:
Rozszerzony opis badania:

To badanie ma być replikacją słynnego eksperymentu Milgrama (1963), który chciał sprawdzić w jakim stopniu posłuszni potrafią być ludzie w określonym kontekście - kiedy polecenia wydaje im osoba autorytarna (w przypadku oryginalnego eksperymentu był to naukowiec, przebrany w biały kitel). 

W swojej replikacji chciałbym jednak wprowadzić pewne zmiany i rozszerzyć ten eksperyment o dwa dodatkowe warunki. 

W oryginalnym eksperymencie, osoby badane dostały informację, że są dzielone na uczniów i nauczyciel (o przydzielonej roli decydowało losowanie). Osoba badana wchodziła jednak zawsze w rolę nauczyciela (losowała spośród samych losów “nauczyciel”) i była wprowadzana w błąd myśląc, że uczniem będzie inna osoba badana. Tak naprawdę w rolę ucznia, który był umieszczany w innym pomieszczeniu, wcielał się pomocnik eksperymentatora, świadomy manipulacji eksperymentalnej oraz prawdziwej intencji badania.

Nauczyciel był proszony o czytanie z listy par słów dla ucznia. Następnie miał przeczytać jedynie jedno słowo z danej pary i podać uczniowi 4 propozycje pasującego słowa. Uczeń odpowiadał klikając na przyciski ponumerowane od 1 do 4, gdzie każda cyfra oznaczała numer odpowiedzi. 

Słowa były czytane do mikrofonu i słyszane przez głośniki umieszczone w pomieszczeniu gdzie przebywał uczeń. Uczeń był dodatkowo rzekomo podpięty pod aparaturę, przez którą nauczyciel mógł aplikować mu wstrząsy elektryczne o różnej mocy (moc mogła być wybrana na urządzeniu, które symulowało generator prądu, przez użycie odpowiedniego przełącznika gdzie każdy kolejny generował prąd większy o 15V).

Przy każdej błędnej odpowiedzi ucznia, nauczyciel miał zastosować karę - wstrząs elektryczny, którego siłę miał zwiększać o 15V po każdej kolejnej błędnej odpowiedzi, aż do pułapu 450 V.


Badany nie widział osoby, której “wymierza karę”, a jedynie słyszał nagrane i zestandaryzowane odpowiedzi werbalne (krzyk, prośby o wypuszczenie). Dodatkowo w pokoju badanego znajdowała się osoba wydająca polecenia. Był to jeden z eksperymentatorów przebrany w biały kitel, odgrywający rolę naukowca. Kiedy osoby badane nie chciały kontynuować eksperymentu eksperymentator ten przekonywał je, by kontynuowały.




Zmiany, które chciałbym wprowadzić w mojej replikacji badania miałyby polegać na tym, by osoby badane były przydzielane do 3 grup (każda grupa odpowiada jednemu warunkowi eksperymentalnemu):

1) Takich, w których słyszą osobę, która jest “karana” 
2) Takich, w których widzą osobę, która jest “karana”
3) Takich, w których widzą i słyszą osobę, która jest “karana”

Zostało przeprowadzonych wiele replikacji i modyfikacji tego badania, żadne jednak nie modyfikowało go w ten sposób. 

Poza wprowadzeniem dodatkowych warunków eksperymentalnych całe badanie będzie przebiegało dokładnie tak jak oryginalny eksperyment Milgrama (1963).

Przed właściwą częścią eksperymentu badany oraz pomocnik eksperymentatora (który będzie udawał drugiego badanego) mają wyciągnąć losy, by stwierdzić, kto będzie odgrywał rolę nauczyciela, a kto ucznia. Badany zawsze będzie nauczycielem (oba losy będą takie same). 

Badani będą mieli do dyspozycji fałszywy generator, który będzie rzekomo podpięty do nadgarstka osoby uczącej się słówek. Będą widzieli odpowiedzi ucznia na ekranie postawionym obok generatora. Dźwięki wydawane przez ucznia będą nagrane, tak by były zestandaryzowane i będą puszczane przez mikrofon i odtwarzane na głośnikach. Głośniki te będą umieszczone koło ekranu, na którym nauczyciel będzie widział odpowiedzi ucznia. 


Eksperymentator w przypadku nieposłuszeństwa osoby badanej, będzie wypowiadał te zdania:

1) Proszę kontynuować

2) Eksperyment wymaga tego by Pan kontynuował

3) To jest absolutnie niezbędne, by Pan kontynuował

4) Nie ma Pan innego wyboru, jak tylko kontynuować

Jeśli któreś z wcześniejszych ponagleń nie przyniesie efektu, eksperymentator przejdzie do do kolejnego, w kolejności od 1 do 4.

Celem tego eksperymentu będzie sprawdzenie:

1) Czy w przypadku warunków drugiego i trzeciego, mniej osób wykona całą procedurę badawczą (tj. dojdzie do siły wstrząsu większej niż 435 V, która byłaby śmiertelna dla ucznia)
2) Czy średnia siła wstrząsu, na której badany zatrzyma procedurę badawczą, będzie różna w zależności od warunku eksperymentalnego.

3) Czy wyniki mojej replikacji będą zbliżone do wyników oryginalnego eksperymentu, pod kątem proporcji ludzi, którzy wykonali całą procedurę badawczą (65%)

4) Czy procent osób, które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą będzie różny w przypadku poszczególnych warunków eksperymentalnych?

registration_responses.q1: Eksperyment Milgrama. Wpływ wzrokowej i słuchowej informacji sensorycznej na uleganie autorytetowi.

Celem tego eksperymentu będzie sprawdzenie czy w przypadku warunków drugiego i trzeciego, mniej osób wykona całą procedurę badawczą (tj. dojdzie do siły wstrząsu większej niż 435 V, która byłaby śmiertelna dla ucznia); czy średnia siła wstrząsu, na której badany zatrzyma procedurę badawczą, będzie różna w zależności od warunku eksperymentalnego oraz czy wyniki mojej replikacji będą zbliżone do wyników oryginalnego eksperymentu, pod kątem proporcji ludzi, którzy wykonali całą procedurę badawczą (65%).
registration_responses.q4:
Hipoteza 1: Średnia siła wstrząsu mierzona w woltach (V) będzie mniejsza w przypadku grup eksperymentalnych, które zostaną poddane warunkowi 2 lub 3, niż w przypadku warunku 1.

Hipoteza 2: Średnia siła wstrząsu mierzona w woltach (V) będzie najmniejsza w przypadku grupy eksperymentalnej poddanej warunkowi 3.


Hipoteza 3: Procent osób, które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w przypadku warunku eksperymentalnego nr 1 będzie zbliżona do wyniku z oryginalnego badania Milgrama (1963) z odchyleniem na poziomie 5%. 

Hipoteza 4: Procent osób, które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w przypadku warunków eksperymentalnych nr 2 i 3 będzie mniejszy niż procent osób, które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w przypadku warunku eksperymentalnego nr 1.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q7:
W przypadku tego badania, osoby badane nie będą wiedziały do której z grup zostaną przydzielone (jedna grupa odpowiada jednemu warunkowi eksperymentalnemu). Ale przede wszystkim nie będą wiedziały jaki jest prawdziwy cel eksperymentu. 

Nie będą również świadome tego, że generator, którym będą mogli aplikować wstrząsy elektryczne jest generatorem symulowanym oraz tego, że tak naprawdę osoba karana nie jest wystawiona na wstrząsy elektryczne.

W samym ogłoszeniu będzie widniała informacja iż jest to badanie na temat "zwiększenia efektywności nauki słówek w języku obcym". Kiedy badany stawi się już na miejscu, zostaje mu przedstawiona następująca informacja:

"Jednym ze sposobów na zwiększenie efektywności uczenia się słówek w języku obcym jest wymierzanie kar. Ale wiemy o tym bardzo mało.

Nie wiemy jaki stopień kary jest najlepszy dla zwiększenia efektywności uczenia się. Nie wiemy też, czy jest różnica kto wymierza karę - osoba młodsza, czy starsza. 

Do tego badania zapraszamy osoby dorosłe o różnym wieku i zawodzie i prosimy ich, by przyjęli rolę nauczyciela lub ucznia. 

Chcielibyśmy dowiedzieć się jaki efekt miałaby kara na uczenie się w takiej sytuacji. DLatego poproszę, by któryś z Państwa przyjął dzisiaj rolę nauczyciela lub ucznia. "

Schemat międzygrupowy wieloczynnikowy. Z dwoma czynnikami: 

1. Widzenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara. Ma dwa poziomy: widzi, nie widzi.

2. Słyszenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara”. Ma dwa poziomy: słyszy, nie słyszy.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Badani będą rekrutowani przez ogłoszenia na grupach facebookowych, co pozwoli dotrzeć do osób z konkretnej grupy wiekowej oraz na portalach ogłoszeniowych (OLX, GumTree).

Każdy uczestnik za udział w badaniu dostanie 50 zł, niezależnie od tego, czy dokończy procedurę badawczą, czy nie (tak by chęć zdobycia pieniędzy nie była czynnikiem zakłócającym). 

Badanie będzie opisane w ogłoszeniu tak jakby dotyczyło sposobów na zwiększenie efektywności nauki słówek w języku obcym. 

Minimalny wiek uczestników to 18 lat. Uczestnicy nie mogą cierpieć na zaburzenia lękowe, depresję, czy inne ciężkie zaburzenia psychiczne. Wykluczani będą również uczestnicy z wadą wzroku i/lub słuchu, chyba że wady te będą skorygowane za pomocą okularów lub aparatu słuchowego. 

Populacja, do której będą kierowane ogłoszenia o badaniu to mieszkańcy Krakowa, w wieku 20 - 50 lat.

Osoby studiujące kognitywistykę, psychologię i kierunki pokrewne nie będą mogły uczestniczyć w badaniu. Studenci takich kierunków mogą znać oryginalne badanie Milgrama, więc badanie ich byłoby bezużyteczne. 

Zgłoszenie do badania będzie odbywało się przez wypełnienie formularza, gdzie osoby zostaną poproszone o podanie podstawowych informacji o sobie, czyli m.in.: wiek, wywiad medyczny pod kątem chorób psychicznych oraz zaburzeń narządów zmysłów, imię i nazwisko.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Zmienne, które będą podlegały manipulacji to: 

1) Widzenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara. Ma dwa poziomy: widzi, nie widzi.


2) Słyszenie osoby, której “wymierzana” jest kara”. Ma dwa poziomy: słyszy, nie słyszy.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Zmienna A: Proporcja osób (wyrażona w procentach), które wykonają całą procedurę badawczą w poszczególnych warunkach eksperymentalnych.

Zmienna B: Średnia siła wstrząsu, na której badani zakończyli procedurę eksperymentalną, w danej grupie eksperymentalnej wyrażona w woltach (V).
registration_responses.q18.question: Brak.
registration_responses.q19.question: Wykorzystam wieloczynnikową ANOVĘ międzygrupową. W celu identyfikacji tego, które grupy istotnie statystycznie  różnią się między sobą zostanie przeprowadzony test post-hoc.

attributes.title: Biological Attributions for Political Ideology and Political Prejudice

q1.value: Biological Attributions for Political Ideology and Political Prejudice

q3.value:
Research question: How does attributing political ideology to biology (i.e. believing that biology/genetics is the main driver of political ideology) influence how people feel about political outgroups?

Background: Scholars have found somewhat contradictory evidence of how biological attributions are related to attitudes. Some work shows that biological attribution is related to less prejudicial attitudes about sexuality (Hegarty 2001; Haider-Markel and Joslyn 2008). Other work shows that biological attribution is related to more prejudicial attitudes involving traits like race or weight (Schneider, Smith, and Hibbing 2018). 

Current study: We argue that biological attributions for political ideology should lead to a decrease in prejudicial attitudes because biological attribution creates a ‘fixed’ representation of political ideology. Meaning, ideology is something that people are born with, therefore people are unable to control this trait and should not be punished for their political ideology. Because of this, people should express less negative attitudes towards people who do not share their political ideology. This argument is similar to what we have seen in attitudes about homosexuality; the argument that sexuality is something people are born with and cannot change should make people more tolerant of homosexuality.

q4.value: Attributing political ideology to biology will lead to reduced political prejudice

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Method: In order to test this hypothesis, we will run an experiment that manipulates attribution of political ideology. Participants will read a vignette about an individual whose political ideology is rooted in biology (attribution treatment 1), personal choices (attribution treatment 2), or not attributed to anything (control). Half of respondents will read about a liberal and half will read about a conservative. The treatment vignettes can be found in the supplemental information below. To measure prejudice, we will ask respondents to indicate how much they like liberals and conservatives on a 7-point Likert scale.

q9.value: Simple randomization will be used for this study. Random treatment assignment will be determined by Qualtrics' randomization method.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Subjects: We will collect this data using respondents from Amazon’s Mechanical Turk. A power analysis suggests we should have at least 63 people per condition with 6 conditions (outgroup biology attribution, outgroup choice attribution, outgroup control, ingroup biology attribution, ingroup choice attribution, ingroup control), for a total N of 378. We intended on collecting data from 400 respondents to account for the possibility of missing data.

We intended on collecting data from 400 respondents to account for the possibility of missing data.

A power analysis suggests we should have at least 63 people per condition with 6 conditions (outgroup biology attribution, outgroup choice attribution, outgroup control, ingroup biology attribution, ingroup choice attribution, ingroup control), for a total N of 378. We intended on collecting data from 400 respondents to account for the possibility of missing data.

question.value: Method: In order to test this hypothesis, we will run an experiment that manipulates attribution of political ideology. Participants will read a vignette about an individual whose political ideology is rooted in biology (attribution treatment 1), personal choices (attribution treatment 2), or not attributed to anything (control). Half of respondents will read about a liberal and half will read about a conservative. The treatment vignettes can be found in the supplemental information below. To measure prejudice, we will ask respondents to indicate how much they like liberals and conservatives on a 7-point Likert scale.

Method: In order to test this hypothesis, we will run an experiment that manipulates attribution of political ideology. Participants will read a vignette about an individual whose political ideology is rooted in biology (attribution treatment 1), personal choices (attribution treatment 2), or not attributed to anything (control). Half of respondents will read about a liberal and half will read about a conservative. The treatment vignettes can be found in the supplemental information below. To measure prejudice, we will ask respondents to indicate how much they like liberals and conservatives on a 7-point Likert scale.

Analysis plan: To analyze the data we will run two OLS regression models. The first will look at the independent effects of attribution type and ideology of subject in vignette (coded as either an ingroup member or outgroup member – group status) on prejudice. The second will include both the main effects and the interaction between attribution type and group status. We expect group status to moderate the effect of attribution type of prejudice because a person’s attitudes about their outgroup could be changed by reading about their outgroup but should not similarly change by reading about their ingroup, since group membership affects social perceptions and judgements (Tajfel 1970; Tajfel et al. 1971).

q23.value: If a respondent does not answer the dependent variable questions, that person will not be included in the analysis. We do not anticipate non-responses to these questions to be systematic.

q1.value: Understanding the relationship between purpose in life and health behaviors

q3.value:
The current study is a follow-up study in which we examined whether values (self-transcendence or self-focused) could increase one’s sense of purpose. Moreover, we also examined whether having an increased purpose as a result from these values lead to greater intentions to exercise. We found surprising results; both types of values lead to an increase in purpose in life however intentions to exercise were only significant for those in self-focused group. These results led to a discussion of why does self-focused and self-transcendence values both increase purpose but intentions to exercise is only significant for those who purpose is increased through self-focused values?

Given that purpose and most health behaviors are self-oriented, does this mean that those who find self-focused values important are better able to make a connection between their purpose and exercising? The current study will examine whether using one’s purpose to get them to engage in health behaviors works if the connection between purpose and health activities are salient and explicit.

q4.value:
1.  Participants who value helping others(self-transcendence value) will report higher purpose in life than those who value focusing on oneself (non-self-transcendence value) and the control.
2. Participants who are able to make a connection between their purpose and health behaviors will report greater intentions to exercise, utilize preventative care services, and get 8 hours of sleep compared to those who don't make a connection between their purpose and health behaviors.
3. Participants who are able to make a connection between their purpose and health behaviors will report greater intentions to exercise, utilize preventative care services, and get 8 hours of sleep compared to their current health behaviors.
3. [Interaction]:  Participants in the self-transcendence condition and in the connection group will report greater intentions to exercise, utilize preventative care services, and get 8 hours of sleep compared to the self-focused group/connection, self-focused/no-connection, self-transcendence/no connection, and the control.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subjects design: 2(Type of Value (self-transcendence, self-focused) x 2(Connection between purpose in life and health behaviors: no connection, connection) + Control

q9.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of five equally sized, predetermined blocks (Type of value and connection between purpose in life and health behaviors). The randomization will occur via Qualtrics randomizer.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Prime Mturk. Participants will be paid $1.67 for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 2000 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 2100, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

question.value:
1. Type of Values: We will manipulate purpose in life through value type: self-transcendence vs non-self transcendence. 

Participants in the self-transcendence value condition will read a prompt that emphasizes the importance of helping others. Next, participants will list three activities they’ve engaged in within the last month to help someone. Participants will then reflect on the importance of helping others and write a brief essay about why helping others is important. Lastly, participants will rate the likelihood of engaging in the activities they’ve just listed in the future.

Participants in the non-self-transcendence value condition will read a prompt that emphasizes the importance of focusing on yourself. Next, participants will list three activities they’ve engaged in within the last month that aimed at focusing on themselves. Participants will then reflect on the importance of focusing on yourself and write a brief essay about why focusing on yourself is important. Lastly, participants will rate the likelihood of engaging in the activities they’ve just listed in the future. 

Participants in the control group will read a prompt about the weather. Participants will then list three factors they think influences the weather. Next, participants will write a brief essay about why they think the factors they’ve just listed influences the weather. Lastly, participants will rate the likelihood of the weather being a hot day tomorrow. 

2. Connection between purpose in life and health behaviors: We will manipulate whether the person is able to make the connection between purpose in life and health behaviors or not by first showing all participants a common list of sources where people derive purpose from and have them identify a source that gives their life a sense of purpose the most.

Those in the yes group (connection between purpose in life and health behaviors) will write 3 activities they do that aligns with their life purpose. Next, these participants will write about why is their health important for carrying out their purpose. Finally, participants will write three health behaviors that will enable them to be carry out their purpose.

Those in the no group (no connection between purpose in life and health behaviors) will complete the same activities as the yes group however the health component will be absent but instead participants will write about activities that gives their life purpose and why are these activities important for carrying out their purpose.
See attached file.

1. Purpose in life: we will add the averages of the three sub-scales to create a single measure of purpose in life.
2. Daily Meaning scale: we will take the mean of the two items that measures daily meaning to create a single measure of daily meaning.
3. Intentions to exercise: We will have two separate measures: vigorous and moderate exercise intentions. For vigorous exercise intentions, we will multiple the number of days participants intend to engage in vigorous exercise by the number of minutes they intend to engage in vigorous exercise per day to create a single measure of amount intended to engage in vigorous exercise. Next, to measure moderate exercise intentions, we will multiple the number of days participants intend to engage in moderate exercise by the number of minutes they intend to engage in moderate exercise per day to create a single measure of amount intended to engage in moderate exercise.
4. Current exercise behavior: We will have two separate measures: current vigorous and moderate exercise levels. For vigorous exercise, we will multiple the number of days participants currently do current vigorous exercise by the number of minutes participants currently do vigorous exercise per day to create a single measure of current vigorous exercise. Next, to measure current moderate exercise, we will multiple the number of days participants currently do moderate exercise by the number of minutes participants currently do moderate exercise per day to create a single measure of current moderate exercise.

Hypothesis 1: Participants who value helping others(self-transcendence value) will report higher purpose in life than those who value focusing on oneself (non-self-transcendence value) and the control. The statistical model that will be used to test this hypothesis will use one-way between subjects ANOVA.

Hypothesis 2: Participants who are able to make a connection between their purpose and health behaviors will report greater intentions to exercise, utilize preventative care services, and get 8 hours of sleep than the no connection and control group. The statistical model that will be used to test this hypothesis is a one-way ANOVA.
 
Hypothesis 3: Participants who are able to make a connection between their purpose and health behaviors will greater intentions to exercise, utilize preventative care services, and get 8 hours of sleep compared to their current health behaviors. The statistical model that will be used to test this hypothesis is an on-way ANOVA.

4. [Interaction]:  Participants in the self-transcendence condition and in the connection group will report greater intentions to exercise, utilize preventative care services, and get 8 hours of sleep compared to the self-focused group/connection, self-focused/no-connection, self-transcendence/no connection, and the control. The statistical model that will be used to test this hypothesis is a 3 x 2 between subjects ANOVA.

q20.value:
We will dummy code "Current preventative health care services behavior" and the Independent variable, connection between purpose in life and health". 

Current preventative health care services consist of four items that assess whether participants have received various preventative health care services this year. "Yes I have received this service" will recoded as "1", "No and I don't plan to receive this service this year" will be recoded as "0" and "No, but I plan to receive this service this year" will be recoded as "99". The reference group will be "1"

The Independent variable, connection between purpose in life and health consist of various activities of making the connection between purpose in life explicit OR not. The connection group will be recoded as 1 and the no connection group will be recoded as 0. The connection group will be the reference group.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA, t-test, and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. The post-hoc Tukey-Kramer test adjusts for multiple comparisons

q23.value: If a participant does not complete all of the surveys, that participant will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to the various health behavior measures. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demographic variables (religion, age, income, and etc) and the health behavior measures. We will also examine the relationships between the demographic variables and purpose/meaning in life.

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
To test for test-retest reliability we will obtain data for meat and plant neophobia using an image scale with 24 items in two sessions.
Our analysis will otherwise be a within-subjects design as the other measures are collected in either the first or the second session (see procedure below).

question3b.value: We will control for participant sex.

question10b.value:
Participants will come to the lab twice for a between-subjects conditioning study. 


In the first session, after completing the other study (see, https://osf.io/9mb6z) participants will answer demographic questions (age, sex), report their hunger level (1=Not hungry at all, 7=Extremely hungry), the last time they have eaten (options include: less than an hour ago, one hour ago, two hours ago, three hours ago…, ten hours ago, more than ten hours ago) and then complete several questionnaires in random order. These questionnaires are “empathy towards animals” questionnaire (Paul, 2000), questions on the frequency of eating meats and plants, liking ratings for six meats and meat-based foods (chicken, steak, hamburger (prepared with ground meat), turkey, ham, sausages) and six plant-based foods (zucchini, carrots, tomatoes, spinach, bananas, apples) on a 7 point Likert scale ( “How much do you like the following foods?”, 1=Not at all, 7= Very much) , the openness subscale of the HEXACO-60 (Ashton & Lee, 2009), the pathogen disgust subscale of Three Domains of Disgust Scale (Tybur, Lieberman, & Griskevicius, 2009), the germ aversion subscale of the Perceived Vulnerability to Disease scale (Duncan, Schaller, & Park, 2009), the Traditional Masculinity and femininity scale (Kachel, Steffens, & Niedlich, 2016), and the Food Neophobia Scale (Pliner & Hobden, 1992). Participants will then see 12 exotic meat and 12 exotic plant images and report whether they would be willing to eat them (“1=Definitely not, 2= Probably not, 3=Probably yes”, 4= Definitely yes”). These questions are part of a previous study (for details see https://osf.io/q3a2x)

In session 2, the research assistant will open the Qualtrics file again but participants will answer only report their hunger level, the last time they have eaten, and answer a subset of the previous questionnaire  (i.e., the 24 item exotic food items). Afterwards participants will receive questions on their frequency of eating meats and plants. Participants will also see pictures of 6 meat (chicken, steak, hamburger (prepared with ground meat), turkey, ham, sausages) and six plant-based foods (zucchini, carrots, tomatoes, spinach, bananas, apples) in random order and rate their willingness to eat them on a 4 point Likert scale (“1=Definitely not, 2= Probably not, 3=Probably yes”, 4= Definitely yes”) . 

Participants will then be fully debriefed.

Note: 
Different from previous survey in https://osf.io/9mb6z we are not including a behavior measure. Also we added eating frequency measure in both sessions to have a better representation of liking meats and plants. We also added separate liking and willingness to eat measures for commonly consumed meat and plant products to check the validity of this eating frequency measure.


References:

1) Ashton, M. C., & Lee, K. (2009). The HEXACO-60: A short measure of the major dimensions of personality. Journal of Personality Assessment, 91, 340-345
2) Pliner, P. & Hobden, K. (1992). Development of a scale to measure the trait of food neophobia in humans. Appetite, 19, 105-120. 
3) Kachel, S., Steffens, M.C., Niedlich, C. (2016). Traditional masculinity and femininity: Validation of a new scale assessing gender roles. Frontiers in Psychology, 7, 956.
4) Paul, E.S. (2000). Empathy with animals and humans: Are they linked?. Anthrozoös: A multidisciplinary journal of the interactions of people and animals, 13, 194-202.
4) Duncan, L.A., Schaller, M., Park, J.H. (2009). Perceived vulnerability to disease: Development and validation of a 15-item self-report instrument. Personality and Individual Differences, 47, 541-546. 
6) Tybur, J. M., Lieberman, D., & Griskevicius, V. (2009). Microbes, mating, and morality: individual differences in three functional domains of disgust. Journal of personality and social psychology, 97(1), 103.

question4b.value: Participants who are not vegan or vegetarian and who are below 35 years old will participate in the study.

question5b.value:
Data will be collected from participants in the psychology labs at Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. 
Participants will come to the lab twice. Data will be collected as part of the study “Are food impressions shaped by unconditioned stimulus valence or content?”  (https://osf.io/9mb6z) that we will be conducting.

question6b.value: We plan on collecting data from 160 participants that participate in both sessions.

question7b.value: We will stop collecting data once we have 160 participants participate in both sessions.

question8b.value: We will exclude participants who report being vegan or vegetarian.

question1a.value:
For the hypotheses and rationale please also check the earlier documentation on the previous follow-up project at (https://osf.io/q3a2x).


1. Plant and meat neophobia will form separate factors.
2. On average, meat neophobia ratings will be higher than plant neophobia ratings.
3. There will be sex differences in meat neophobia, such that women will score higher on meat neophobia.  
4. Food Neophobia Scale will be correlated with meat neophobia and plant neophobia.

We will test different predictors for meat and plant neophobia. The four hypotheses compiled include disgust sensitivity, masculinity, empathy towards animals, and liking meat. We will statistically test how the variance in meat neophobia and plant neophobia is explained by each.

5. Meat eating behaviors are argued to have their basis in the existing associations of meat eating with masculinity (Heinz & Lee, 1998: Rozin et al., 2012). Meat neophobia might be lower in men because men associate meat eating as a masculine behavior. In this case we expect those who rate themselves as more masculineto show lower meat neophobia ratings.

6.Research also points that empathy might be affecting individuals’ approach towards meat. Rothberger and Mican (2014) showed that empathy towards animals mediates the relationship between pet attachment and meat avoidance. Aligned with this research, empathy towards animals will positively correlate with meat neophobia.

7. Meats pose an asymmetrical danger compared to plants and researchers argue that disgust plays a significant role in solving this adaptive problem, such that meats are always at the center of food taboos and taste aversions (Fessler & Navarrete, 2003). In line with this literature, pathogen disgust might explain variance in meat neophobia.Results from our first study are not consistent with this hypothesis. We aimed to again test this hypothesis again using the TDDS (Tybur, Lieberman, & Griskevicius, 2009) and also the Germ Aversion subscale of Perceived Vulnerability to Disease scale (Duncan, Schaller, & Park, 2009). Hence, the pathogen avoidance explanation will be tested with two separate measures.

8.Finally, meat neophobia might simply be a by-product of individual differences in liking meat. Someone who does not like meat in the first place may be less open to trying novel meats. Hence, if meat neophobia is a by-product of meat liking, then we will expect frequency in eating meat to explain the variance in meat neophobia. We would also expect evidence to corroborate this when we look at the relationship between meat neophobia and  self-report liking on commonly consumed meats.

question1c.value:
We will calculate composite scores for meat neophobia and plant neophobia. 
We will also calculate composites for masculinity, empathy twd animals, pathogen disgust, openness to new experiences, germ aversion, and FNS as described in the literature.  
We will add number of meats and plants consumed on the time window by summing up the reported values. 

We will test for dimensionality of the reported willingness eating common meat/plants acquired in Session 2. We expect them to form separate factors. We will create composite scores for reported liking on meats and plants.

question2c.value:
The dimensionality of food neophobia will be explored with principal axis factor analysis. 

We will mainly use the General Linear Model with standardized variables to test for these predictions.

question3c.value:
We will test for main effects of participant sex and food type on food neophobia, and we will test the interaction between these two variables.
We will also test how meat and plant neophobia relate to masculinity, openness, disgust sensitivity (as measured with pathogen disgust and germ aversion), frequency of eating meats and plants, liking of meats and plants, willingness eating common meats and plants, and animal empathy. We will control for participant sex when we are testing how meat and plant neophobia relate to other variables (e.g., disgust sensitivity, masculinity...) Controlling for participant sex, we will also test to see how strongly these two types of food neophobia relate to the food neophobia scale.  
We will also examine the test-retest reliability of the meat and plant neophobia image scales.

question4c.value:
In the literature women tend to be high on disgust sensitivity (Sparks et al., in press) and tend to eat meat less than men do (Beardsworth & Bryman, 1999; Fessler, Arguello, Mekdara, & Macias, 2003).  In order to make sure that participant sex is not confounding our results, we will control for participant sex.

References:
Beardsworth, A., & Bryman, A. (1999). Meat consumption and vegetarianism among young adults in the UK. British Food Journal, 101, 289–300
Fessler, D.M.T., Arguello, A.P., Mekdara, J.M., & Macias, R. (2003). Disgust sensitivity and meat consumption: a test of an emotivist account of moral vegetarianism. Appetite, 41, 31-41.
Sparks, A. M., Fessler, D. M., Chan, K. Q., Ashokkumar, A., & Holbrook, C. (2018). Disgust as a mechanism for decision making under risk: illuminating sex differences and individual risk-taking correlates of disgust propensity. Emotion (in press).

attributes.title: Identifying potential mismatches between objective need and mental health-care use over time in people with depression and/or anxiety.
attributes.description: observational longitudinal study on describing mismatch and match between mental health-care needs and mental health-care use

q1.value: Identifying potential mismatches between objective need and mental health-care use over time in people with depression and/or anxiety.

q2.value: Kalpani Wijekoon Wijekoon Mudiyanselage, Frederike Jörg, Jojanneke A. Bastiaansen, Roy Stewart, Klaas Wardenaar, Brenda Penninx, Bert van Hemert, Robert A. Schoevers

q3.value: There are evidence-based treatments for different severity levels of affective disorders, but the type and amount of received mental health-care does not necessarily match a person’s objective need (i.e., the clinically assessed diagnosis and its severity) (Philip S. Wang, 2010; Verhaak, 2009). A mismatch between the need and use of mental health-care can occur as under-and overutilization, which can have serious consequences on an individual, societal and economic level (Adams & Wrath, 2018; Druss et al., 2008; Jureidini & Tonkin, 2006; Mcdaid, 2011). Previous studies were mainly cross-sectional (Verhaak, 2009; WHO World Mental Health Consortium, 2019) or did not include different health-care services (Kooistra et al., 2018), limiting investigations of help seeking patterns in people with affective disorders, which are typically persistent and recurring in nature. Therefore, in this study, we investigate mismatches between objective need and mental health-care use in people with depression and anxiety, in a longitudinal study design based on the Netherlands Study of Depression and Anxiety (NESDA). This way, we can create a more accurate picture of under-and overutilization, which will serve as a valid basis for future research.

q4.value:
Given the exploratory nature of our study our hypotheses are relatively broad:

1.	Our hypothesis is that we will be able to distinguish groups with varying care consumption patterns in people with (high risk) depression and/or anxiety and healthy controls over time, which can be either adequately matched to objective need or show a mismatch with objective need i.e., the clinically assessed diagnosis and severity of mental disorders, which are thoroughly assessed in this study of patients with depression and anxiety disorders (Druss et al., 2008; Verhaak, 2009). 

This hypothesis was based on previous (cross-sectional) studies indicating the presence of over-and underutilization of mental health-care services (Bet et al., 2013; Jörg et al., 2016; Verhaak, 2009).

2.	Second, we hypothesize that, according to Anderson’s health-behaviour model (Andersen, 2008; Birgit Babitsch, Daniela Gohl, 2012), enabling factors, need factors and predisposing factors can influence the presence of a mismatch or a match between objective need and mental health-care use. Hence, we will explore whether the following factors differentially describe the mismatch and match groups: 1. Predisposing factos such as age, sex, 2. enabling factors such as socio-economic status 3. Need factors such as attitudes towards mental health-care, subjective need, presence of a comorbid chronic disease, severity of depressive and anxiety symptoms, suicidal ideation, presence of other psychiatric disorders which were diagnosed in the follow-up period (bipolar disorder, PTSD), high risk* of depression and/or anxiety disorders. 

* A High risk population is defined as adults with subthreshold symptoms of depression and/or anxiety and adults whose parents were treated for anxiety and depressive disorders as outpatients at a mental health organization (Penninx et al., 2008).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study has an observational, longitudinal design, based on the existing cohort study called NESDA (Netherlands Study of Depression and Anxiety) (Penninx et al., 2008).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
Before accessing the data from the NESDA cohort, we wrote and submitted a publication plan, in which we outlined the background, specific research questions, methodology, proposed statistical analysis and an overview of all the variables we intend to use for this study, each indicated with a variable code. Next, an internal committee of NESDA researchers examined the planning, novelty, practical implications and feasibility of this proposal and granted us access to the data. Thereupon, we could select the variables that were mentioned in the proposal, which was first verified by a data management expert and then available for download. The publication plan formed the basis for this preregistration.

Our first hypothesis is based on a previous NESDA study, which indicated the presence of a mismatch between use and need of mental health-care (Verhaak, 2009). However, this study was of cross-sectional nature, which did not allow to find different trajectories of mismatch between use and need of mental health-care. Furthermore, to our knowledge one other longitudinal NESDA study was conducted which as well found the presence of underutilization (Kooistra et al., 2018). However, this study looked at the transition from no or primary care to specialized care over time, and therefore did not take all the different health-care services into account.

Hence, there is no previous NESDA study on the identification of trajectories of mismatch between need and use of mental health-care, taking different health-care services into account.

question.value: We use existing data from the NESDA cohort. NESDA is a multisite, naturalistic cohort study Netherland Study of Depression and Anxiety that investigates long-term courses of people with depression and/or anxiety and their use of different health-care services. The cohort consists of 2981 participants, aged 18-65 years. Recruitment took place at the GP, and in primary mental health-care and specialized mental health-care settings. The participants had (high risk of) depressive and/or anxiety disorders or were healthy controls. The data of the participants were collected at baseline and 1, 2, 4, 6 and 9 years after baseline. A more detailed description about the procedures of the NESDA study can be found elsewhere (Penninx et al., 2008).

q13.value:
The NESDA baseline sample size consists of n= 2981 (Penninx et al., 2008). 
We will conduct the latent class growth analysis (LCGA) using a full information maximum likelihood estimator, hence every person who completed two or more waves will be taken into account.

q14.value:
Given that we are working with a preexisting cohort study, the sample size was fixed in advance (n=2069). As LCGA is a data-exploration technique rather than a method to test a simple null-hypothesis, a power calculation can be simulated by means of a Monte Carlo study, in order to be able to decide whether a sample size is sufficient (Muthén & Muthén, 2012)

  Moreover, several previously published studies that successfully used LCGA to estimate subgroups with different depression course trajectories used smaller or comparable sample sizes(n=205-2,660) (Mowbray, Mcbeath, Bank, & Newell, 2016; Wardenaar, Monden, Conradi, & Jonge, 2015; Weeghel, Id, Schaefer, Weeghel, & Mulder, 2019). We therefore assume having an adequate sample size to estimate meaningful classes.

question.value:
Outcome variables for the main analysis:

1.	Objective need 
Objective need is defined as the presence of a current (6 month prevalence) diagnosis and severity of a depressive and/or anxiety disorder. The diagnosis is based on the composite international diagnostic interview (CIDI) – lifetime version 2.1, which is based on the DSM-IV and ICD-10 criteria (Burke, Regier, & Sartorius, 1988). 
The severity of the diagnosed disorder was measured by the life-chart questionnaire (Penninx et al., 2008).The life-chart interview retrospectively assesses the associated burden of present depression and/or anxiety symptoms for each month during the 9-year follow-up period. The symptom burden was rated on a 4-point scale ranging from 0=no/minimal symptoms to 4= symptoms with severe burden. 
In order to increase the accuracy of this retrospective assessment, the respondents were asked to name important events that happened during the follow-up period to refresh their memory.  Given that more recent assessments tend to be more accurate and given that health care use was also retrospectively assessed across 6-month periods, we decided to use assessments of symptom burden across the last 6 months before each follow-up assessment. 


2.	 Use of mental health-care assessed with the TIC-P questionnaire

The Tic-P is a generic questionnaire that includes 11 questions about type and frequency of health-care services used within the past 6 months (Bouwmans et al., 2013) .

3.	Explanatory variables for the post-hoc analysis 
 
Demographic variables: Sex (male, female), age, education. 

Attitudes towards mental health care: Nivel self-reported questionnaire. 

Subjective need: PNCQ interview.

Presence of a chronic disease: Self-report questions chronic diseases.

Severity of depressive symptoms: Inventory of depressive symptoms. 

Severity of anxiety symptoms: Beck anxiety index.

Suicidal ideation:  Beck suicidal ideation.

Presence of bipolar disorder: CIDI bipolar. 

Presence of post-traumatic stress disorder: PTSS-scale of complaints PSS-I. 

Type of mental-health care setting: Tic-P.

1.	Objective need: composite score of the CIDI and the Life-time questionnaire 

In order to enable the identification of mental health-care need over time we will develop a composite score of the CIDI questionnaire and the Life-time questionnaire. Therefore, to also include participants with no diagnosis, we aim to transform the initial 4-point scale of the Life-chart questionnaire into a 5-point scale, defining 0= no diagnosis, 1= diagnosis and no/minimal symptoms 2= diagnosis and mild symptoms, 3= diagnosis and moderate symptoms, 4= diagnosis severe/very severe. 

2.	Mental health-care use: Weighted scoring of the Tic-P questionnaire 
Since the severity of disorder determines the type of mental health-service and thus the corresponding costs for each session, we weighted each type of service differently, e.g. GP= 66 EUR and hospitalization=302 EUR (Roijen, Linden, Bouwmans, Kanters, & Tan, 2015). We will therefore standardize each mental health-care service cost based on the CBS index costs (CBS, 2019). Afterwards a composite score will be generated for mental health care use by multiplying the frequency of usage with the standardized expenses for one session in each type of mental health-care service used, based on the Dutch guidelines for economic evaluations of health-care (Roijen et al., 2015)

We will use the parallel process latent class growth analysis (LCGA) to identify potential mismatch and match trajectories. 

We will conduct multiple comparison testing for the second hypothesis, to describe these potential mismatch and match classes.

q20.value: We will generate composite scores for the main variables: mental health-care use and objective need, for further explanation see the above-mentioned sections.

q21.value:
For the first analysis, we will estimate LCGA models with increasing numbers of classes and will use information criteria (Akaike and Bayesian Information Criterion) to select the optimal model given the data (Hoyle, 2012). However, parsimony and interpretability will also be taken into account because these measures do not always agree.  

For the second analysis, the Bonferroni correction, confidence intervals and effect sized will be used when describing the groups post-hoc based on multiple comparisons.

q22.value: We will investigate the distribution of the data through boxplots and we will handle outliers by trimming or recoding to missing values (Wilcox RR, 2001). Furthermore, If the model cannot be identified because of potential remaining outliers we will use weighted least squares information instead of maximum likelihood estimation.

q23.value: For second analysis we will use multiple imputation, if the number of missing cases is large and can be compared to the complete cases.

q24.value:
In this study we will conduct an exploratory analysis, to identify different patterns of mismatch and match trajectories for objective need and mental health-care use. For the analysis, Mplus and SPSS will be used. To identify the course-specific classes, latent class growth analysis (LCGA) will be performed for objective need and mental health-care use separately. LCGA is a statistical method, classifying individuals into classes based on their most probable longitudinal response patterns on each variable. It is a very suitable method to identify inter-individual differences in intra-individual change (Jung & Wickrama, 2008). 

Afterwards, identified trajectories of these two variables will be combined. Thus, a parallel process latent class growth analysis (pp-LCGA) will be used to identify classes based on simultaneous trajectories for both variables, namely objective need and mental health-care use (Muthén & Muthén, 2012). This can help to identify mismatch and match between trajectories of objective need and use of mental healthcare over time. The model fit will be assessed using criteria such as the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), to decide for the number of classes. 

Once the classes have been identified, we will descriptively assess the relationship between the explanatory variables and the classes and conduct multiple comparison testing. Therefore, depending on whether the outcome classes are ordinal or not, we will use ordinal logistic regression or multinomial logistic regression.

registration_responses.q1: Identifying potential mismatches between objective need and mental health-care use over time in people with depression and/or anxiety.
registration_responses.q2: Kalpani Wijekoon Wijekoon Mudiyanselage, Frederike Jörg, Jojanneke A. Bastiaansen, Roy Stewart, Klaas Wardenaar, Brenda Penninx, Bert van Hemert, Robert A. Schoevers
registration_responses.q3: There are evidence-based treatments for different severity levels of affective disorders, but the type and amount of received mental health-care does not necessarily match a person’s objective need (i.e., the clinically assessed diagnosis and its severity) (Philip S. Wang, 2010; Verhaak, 2009). A mismatch between the need and use of mental health-care can occur as under-and overutilization, which can have serious consequences on an individual, societal and economic level (Adams & Wrath, 2018; Druss et al., 2008; Jureidini & Tonkin, 2006; Mcdaid, 2011). Previous studies were mainly cross-sectional (Verhaak, 2009; WHO World Mental Health Consortium, 2019) or did not include different health-care services (Kooistra et al., 2018), limiting investigations of help seeking patterns in people with affective disorders, which are typically persistent and recurring in nature. Therefore, in this study, we investigate mismatches between objective need and mental health-care use in people with depression and anxiety, in a longitudinal study design based on the Netherlands Study of Depression and Anxiety (NESDA). This way, we can create a more accurate picture of under-and overutilization, which will serve as a valid basis for future research.
registration_responses.q4:
Given the exploratory nature of our study our hypotheses are relatively broad:

1.	Our hypothesis is that we will be able to distinguish groups with varying care consumption patterns in people with (high risk) depression and/or anxiety and healthy controls over time, which can be either adequately matched to objective need or show a mismatch with objective need i.e., the clinically assessed diagnosis and severity of mental disorders, which are thoroughly assessed in this study of patients with depression and anxiety disorders (Druss et al., 2008; Verhaak, 2009). 

This hypothesis was based on previous (cross-sectional) studies indicating the presence of over-and underutilization of mental health-care services (Bet et al., 2013; Jörg et al., 2016; Verhaak, 2009).

2.	Second, we hypothesize that, according to Anderson’s health-behaviour model (Andersen, 2008; Birgit Babitsch, Daniela Gohl, 2012), enabling factors, need factors and predisposing factors can influence the presence of a mismatch or a match between objective need and mental health-care use. Hence, we will explore whether the following factors differentially describe the mismatch and match groups: 1. Predisposing factos such as age, sex, 2. enabling factors such as socio-economic status 3. Need factors such as attitudes towards mental health-care, subjective need, presence of a comorbid chronic disease, severity of depressive and anxiety symptoms, suicidal ideation, presence of other psychiatric disorders which were diagnosed in the follow-up period (bipolar disorder, PTSD), high risk* of depression and/or anxiety disorders. 

* A High risk population is defined as adults with subthreshold symptoms of depression and/or anxiety and adults whose parents were treated for anxiety and depressive disorders as outpatients at a mental health organization (Penninx et al., 2008).
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q7: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
Before accessing the data from the NESDA cohort, we wrote and submitted a publication plan, in which we outlined the background, specific research questions, methodology, proposed statistical analysis and an overview of all the variables we intend to use for this study, each indicated with a variable code. Next, an internal committee of NESDA researchers examined the planning, novelty, practical implications and feasibility of this proposal and granted us access to the data. Thereupon, we could select the variables that were mentioned in the proposal, which was first verified by a data management expert and then available for download. The publication plan formed the basis for this preregistration.

Our first hypothesis is based on a previous NESDA study, which indicated the presence of a mismatch between use and need of mental health-care (Verhaak, 2009). However, this study was of cross-sectional nature, which did not allow to find different trajectories of mismatch between use and need of mental health-care. Furthermore, to our knowledge one other longitudinal NESDA study was conducted which as well found the presence of underutilization (Kooistra et al., 2018). However, this study looked at the transition from no or primary care to specialized care over time, and therefore did not take all the different health-care services into account.

Hence, there is no previous NESDA study on the identification of trajectories of mismatch between need and use of mental health-care, taking different health-care services into account.
registration_responses.q13:
The NESDA baseline sample size consists of n= 2981 (Penninx et al., 2008). 
We will conduct the latent class growth analysis (LCGA) using a full information maximum likelihood estimator, hence every person who completed two or more waves will be taken into account.
registration_responses.q14:
Given that we are working with a preexisting cohort study, the sample size was fixed in advance (n=2069). As LCGA is a data-exploration technique rather than a method to test a simple null-hypothesis, a power calculation can be simulated by means of a Monte Carlo study, in order to be able to decide whether a sample size is sufficient (Muthén & Muthén, 2012)

  Moreover, several previously published studies that successfully used LCGA to estimate subgroups with different depression course trajectories used smaller or comparable sample sizes(n=205-2,660) (Mowbray, Mcbeath, Bank, & Newell, 2016; Wardenaar, Monden, Conradi, & Jonge, 2015; Weeghel, Id, Schaefer, Weeghel, & Mulder, 2019). We therefore assume having an adequate sample size to estimate meaningful classes.
registration_responses.q20: We will generate composite scores for the main variables: mental health-care use and objective need, for further explanation see the above-mentioned sections.
registration_responses.q21:
For the first analysis, we will estimate LCGA models with increasing numbers of classes and will use information criteria (Akaike and Bayesian Information Criterion) to select the optimal model given the data (Hoyle, 2012). However, parsimony and interpretability will also be taken into account because these measures do not always agree.  

For the second analysis, the Bonferroni correction, confidence intervals and effect sized will be used when describing the groups post-hoc based on multiple comparisons.
registration_responses.q22: We will investigate the distribution of the data through boxplots and we will handle outliers by trimming or recoding to missing values (Wilcox RR, 2001). Furthermore, If the model cannot be identified because of potential remaining outliers we will use weighted least squares information instead of maximum likelihood estimation.
registration_responses.q23: For second analysis we will use multiple imputation, if the number of missing cases is large and can be compared to the complete cases.
registration_responses.q24:
In this study we will conduct an exploratory analysis, to identify different patterns of mismatch and match trajectories for objective need and mental health-care use. For the analysis, Mplus and SPSS will be used. To identify the course-specific classes, latent class growth analysis (LCGA) will be performed for objective need and mental health-care use separately. LCGA is a statistical method, classifying individuals into classes based on their most probable longitudinal response patterns on each variable. It is a very suitable method to identify inter-individual differences in intra-individual change (Jung & Wickrama, 2008). 

Afterwards, identified trajectories of these two variables will be combined. Thus, a parallel process latent class growth analysis (pp-LCGA) will be used to identify classes based on simultaneous trajectories for both variables, namely objective need and mental health-care use (Muthén & Muthén, 2012). This can help to identify mismatch and match between trajectories of objective need and use of mental healthcare over time. The model fit will be assessed using criteria such as the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) and Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), to decide for the number of classes. 

Once the classes have been identified, we will descriptively assess the relationship between the explanatory variables and the classes and conduct multiple comparison testing. Therefore, depending on whether the outcome classes are ordinal or not, we will use ordinal logistic regression or multinomial logistic regression.
