registration_responses.q8.question: This study has an observational, longitudinal design, based on the existing cohort study called NESDA (Netherlands Study of Depression and Anxiety) (Penninx et al., 2008).
registration_responses.q12.question: We use existing data from the NESDA cohort. NESDA is a multisite, naturalistic cohort study Netherland Study of Depression and Anxiety that investigates long-term courses of people with depression and/or anxiety and their use of different health-care services. The cohort consists of 2981 participants, aged 18-65 years. Recruitment took place at the GP, and in primary mental health-care and specialized mental health-care settings. The participants had (high risk of) depressive and/or anxiety disorders or were healthy controls. The data of the participants were collected at baseline and 1, 2, 4, 6 and 9 years after baseline. A more detailed description about the procedures of the NESDA study can be found elsewhere (Penninx et al., 2008).
registration_responses.q17.question:
Outcome variables for the main analysis:

1.	Objective need 
Objective need is defined as the presence of a current (6 month prevalence) diagnosis and severity of a depressive and/or anxiety disorder. The diagnosis is based on the composite international diagnostic interview (CIDI) – lifetime version 2.1, which is based on the DSM-IV and ICD-10 criteria (Burke, Regier, & Sartorius, 1988). 
The severity of the diagnosed disorder was measured by the life-chart questionnaire (Penninx et al., 2008).The life-chart interview retrospectively assesses the associated burden of present depression and/or anxiety symptoms for each month during the 9-year follow-up period. The symptom burden was rated on a 4-point scale ranging from 0=no/minimal symptoms to 4= symptoms with severe burden. 
In order to increase the accuracy of this retrospective assessment, the respondents were asked to name important events that happened during the follow-up period to refresh their memory.  Given that more recent assessments tend to be more accurate and given that health care use was also retrospectively assessed across 6-month periods, we decided to use assessments of symptom burden across the last 6 months before each follow-up assessment. 


2.	 Use of mental health-care assessed with the TIC-P questionnaire

The Tic-P is a generic questionnaire that includes 11 questions about type and frequency of health-care services used within the past 6 months (Bouwmans et al., 2013) .

3.	Explanatory variables for the post-hoc analysis 
 
Demographic variables: Sex (male, female), age, education. 

Attitudes towards mental health care: Nivel self-reported questionnaire. 

Subjective need: PNCQ interview.

Presence of a chronic disease: Self-report questions chronic diseases.

Severity of depressive symptoms: Inventory of depressive symptoms. 

Severity of anxiety symptoms: Beck anxiety index.

Suicidal ideation:  Beck suicidal ideation.

Presence of bipolar disorder: CIDI bipolar. 

Presence of post-traumatic stress disorder: PTSS-scale of complaints PSS-I. 

Type of mental-health care setting: Tic-P.
registration_responses.q18.question:
1.	Objective need: composite score of the CIDI and the Life-time questionnaire 

In order to enable the identification of mental health-care need over time we will develop a composite score of the CIDI questionnaire and the Life-time questionnaire. Therefore, to also include participants with no diagnosis, we aim to transform the initial 4-point scale of the Life-chart questionnaire into a 5-point scale, defining 0= no diagnosis, 1= diagnosis and no/minimal symptoms 2= diagnosis and mild symptoms, 3= diagnosis and moderate symptoms, 4= diagnosis severe/very severe. 

2.	Mental health-care use: Weighted scoring of the Tic-P questionnaire 
Since the severity of disorder determines the type of mental health-service and thus the corresponding costs for each session, we weighted each type of service differently, e.g. GP= 66 EUR and hospitalization=302 EUR (Roijen, Linden, Bouwmans, Kanters, & Tan, 2015). We will therefore standardize each mental health-care service cost based on the CBS index costs (CBS, 2019). Afterwards a composite score will be generated for mental health care use by multiplying the frequency of usage with the standardized expenses for one session in each type of mental health-care service used, based on the Dutch guidelines for economic evaluations of health-care (Roijen et al., 2015)
registration_responses.q19.question:
We will use the parallel process latent class growth analysis (LCGA) to identify potential mismatch and match trajectories. 

We will conduct multiple comparison testing for the second hypothesis, to describe these potential mismatch and match classes.

attributes.title: Delay or decay? Brain age in individuals with autism spectrum disorder

q1.value: Delay or decay? Brain maturation, IQ and symptom severity in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.

q2.value: Philippe Jawinski, Emily Volbert, Sebastian Markett

q3.value:
To gain novel insights into structural brain differences and brain maturation in people with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), this study seeks to investigate the biological age of the brain by using the open source datasets ABIDE I and II. We will use structural MRI data and supervised machine learning to estimate each participant’s brain age gap, that is the difference between the brain-predicted age and the chronological age of the individual. A larger brain age gap (indicative for accelerated brain aging) has been shown to be associated with various brain disorders, such as schizophrenia, bipolar spectrum disorders, multiple sclerosis, mild cognitive impairment, and dementia (Kaufmann et al., 2019). Consistently, a growing body of evidence suggests that brain age is linked to physical, cognitive and mental health (Cole, Marioni, Harris, & Deary, 2019; Gaser & Franke, 2019), and may serve as a prospective indicator for Alzheimer’s disease (Franke & Gaser, 2012) as well as mortality (Cole et al., 2018). Due to its involvement in neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases, brain age also appears to be an encouraging marker for neurodevelopmental disorders such as ASD.

ASD is associated with delays in developmental mile stones, such as delays in the development of motor skills (Provost, Lopez, & Heimerl, 2007) and language (Matson, Mahan, Kozlowski, & Shoemaker, 2010). This may suggest an underlying delay of brain development in individuals with ASD. Furthermore, previous studies have shown a link between ASD and pronounced age-related cortical thinning (Khundrakpam, Lewis, Kostopoulos, Carbonell, & Evans, 2017) and initial increase followed by accelerated decrease in overall brain volume (Courchesne, Campbell, & Solso, 2011; Lange et al., 2015). These findings may suggest that the brain ages prematurely in individuals with ASD. Nevertheless, Kaufman et al. (2019) directly investigated brain age in ASD and reported no significant differences in affected individuals when compared to healthy controls. The authors used data from the open source database ABIDE (http://fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/abide/), which provides a variety of MRI and psychometric data for individuals with ASD and healthy controls on a broad age spectrum. Notably, the vast majority of ABIDE participants, including those with ASD, show average or above-average intelligence (Di Martino et al., 2014). This raises the question whether individuals with ASD in the ABIDE dataset rather represent “high functioning ASD”, which may result in only subtle differences in brain morphology when compared to healthy controls. In this case, research on brain ageing in ASD may crucially benefit from taking into account the available information on symptom severity and cognitive functioning.

In keeping with this, previous studies showed that more severe autistic symptoms are also accompanied by more pronounced structural brain aberrations (Chaste et al., 2013; Hazlett et al., 2017; Khundrakpam et al., 2017). Additionally, autistic symptoms typically improve with age, and especially repetitive behaviors can be mostly observed during childhood (Esbensen, Seltzer, Lam, & Bodfish, 2009; Shattuck et al., 2007). Therefore, taking into account symptom severity might be more conclusive when looking at brain maturation in individuals with ASD than solely considering diagnosis status. Consequently, this study aims to investigate if symptom severity is associated with the extent to which brain ageing is altered in individuals with ASD.

Although cognitive impairment is not a symptom of ASD, individuals with ASD often have an intellectual disability. Baio and colleagues (2018) found that among 8-years-old individuals with ASD, 31% had an intellectual disability (IQ ≤ 70) and 25% had an IQ lower than or equal to 85. The combination of ASD and intellectual disability is commonly referred to as “low functioning ASD”. Individuals with ASD and average or above-average IQ are usually more independent in everyday activities and have a higher chance of occupation (Billstedt, Gillberg, & Gillberg, 2011). Although it is unclear how IQ relates to brain age in children and adolescents, in healthy adults, higher cognitive functioning has been associated with lower brain age gap (Poulton, Ramrakha, Caspi, Moffitt, & Ahmad, 2019). On this account, we seek to investigate whether cognitive functioning is associated with brain age in a sample of children, adolescents and adults with and without ASD. In addition, higher levels of general intelligence might be a protective factor in ASD. Thus, we want to examine whether general intelligence may interact with diagnosis status and symptom severity, respectively, in predicting the biological age of the brain. 

While a lower brain age gap has commonly been linked to beneficial health outcomes, this may reasonably not apply to developmental disorders and cognitive functioning in children and adolescents. In an exploratory analysis, we will thus investigate if age moderates the association between brain age gap and each of our variables of interest (diagnosis status, symptom severity, and IQ).


To summarize, this study aims to investigate if diagnosis status, IQ, and diagnosis status x IQ impact the biological age of the brain. Further, we will address whether symptom severity, IQ, and symptom severity x IQ impact on brain age in individuals with ASD. In an exploratory manner, we will further address whether age moderates the associations between brain age and each of our variables of interest (diagnosis group, symptom severity, and IQ).

References

Baio, J., Wiggins, L., Christensen, D. L., Maenner, M. J., Daniels, J., Warren, Z., … Dowling, N. F. (2018). Prevalence of autism spectrum disorder among children aged 8 Years - Autism and developmental disabilities monitoring network, 11 Sites, United States, 2014. MMWR Surveillance Summaries, 67(6). https://doi.org/10.15585/mmwr.ss6706a1

Billstedt, E., Gillberg, I. C., & Gillberg, C. (2011). Aspects of quality of life in adults diagnosed with autism in childhood: A population-based study. Autism, 15(1), 7–20. https://doi.org/10.1177/1362361309346066

Chaste, P., Klei, L., Sanders, S. J., Murtha, M. T., Hus, V., Lowe, J. K., … Kim, S. J. (2013). Adjusting head circumference for covariates in autism: Clinical correlates of a highly heritable continuous trait. Biological Psychiatry, 74(8), 576–584. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.biopsych.2013.04.018

Cole, J. H., Ritchie, S. J., Bastin, M. E., Valdés Hernández, M. C., Muñoz Maniega, S., Royle, N., … Deary, I. J. (2018). Brain age predicts mortality. Molecular Psychiatry, 23(5), 1385–1392. https://doi.org/10.1038/mp.2017.62

Brain maturation: brain age gap based on structural MRI data

For each individual in the ABIDE I and II datasets, we will estimate brain age by applying supervised machine learning methods to structural T1 magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data. In the following, we describe the procedure of how we will derive brain age estimates. 

MRI preprocessing. Structural T1 magnetic resonance imaging data will be preprocessed using the voxel-based morphometry pipeline of cat12 (r1364, http://dbm.neuro.uni-jena.de) for spm12 (r7487) in Matlab 2018b. In brief, preprocessing involves affine and DARTEL registration of brain images to a reference brain, segmentation into gray matter, white matter, and cerebro-spinal fluid, bias correction for intensity inhomogeneity, and modulation of segmentations to account for the amount of volume changes due to spatial registration. Processed images will be smoothed by applying the 8x8x8mm full-width-at-half-maximum (FWHM) gaussian kernel with subsequent resampling to 8mm3 voxel size. We have previously published a script with detailed cat12 settings on the OSF server (https://osf.io/pbd5w/).

Feature set for machine learning. We will estimate the biological age of the brain from both gray and white matter segmentations. The preprocessed images will comprise 16128 voxels each. We will exclude voxels that do not show any variation across individuals (e.g. background voxels). Typically, voxel-based images are characterized by substantial spatial correlations. To remove redundant information and reduce dimensionality, we will conduct a principal component analysis (PCA) using the Matlab built-in function pca. Notably, Franke et al. (2010) reported a higher accuracy of the age estimation models when a larger number of principal components was entered into the prediction models. Our own previous analyses in unrelated data sets suggest that the first 500 principal components will capture more than 90% of the total variance, and will enable model training in a reasonable period of time with advanced computational resources.

Machine learning algorithms. Age estimation models will be trained using a sparse Bayesian vector machine in Matlab (Tipping, 2001), and the gradient boosting package ‘xgboost’ v.0.82.1 in R (Chen et al., 2019). The relevance vector machine (RVM) was developed as a probabilistic equivalent to the popular support vector regression (SVR). It uses Bayesian inference and its solutions are particularly sparse in the sense that they utilize fewer kernel functions than SVR. We will make use of the RVM using the SparseBayes v.2 toolbox in Matlab with the wrapper and kernel function by Qiu (2019).

Further, we will apply the xgboost algorithms, which have been widely used in the field of supervised machine learning. We will train our models with both the tree and linear gradient booster. The learning rate will be set to eta = 0.02 with 5000 training iterations and an early-stopping after 50 iterations in the case of no further model improvement. The maximum tree depth will be set to 3. Default settings will be used for all other training parameters. We previously published an R script with the specified settings on the OSF server (https://osf.io/xdnjb/).

Model training and application. Age estimation models will be trained with the first 500 principal components serving as features (as described above) and chronological age serving as outcome variable. Model training will be carried out in healthy controls by pursuing a tenfold cross-validation approach with 100 repeats. Models will be applied to both healthy controls (those who are not used for model training) and individuals with autism. We will randomly split the healthy control sample into ten equal-sized subsets. Nine of the ten subsets will serve as training sample, while the remaining subset and all individuals with autism will serve as test sample. Brain images of the training sample will undergo PCA, and transformation parameters will subsequently be applied to calculate pca scores in the test sample. After the first model is trained and tested, the next subset and all autism individuals serve as test sample, while the other nine healthy control subsets are selected as training sample. This procedure is carried on until each subset will have served exactly once as test sample. The tenfold cross-validation procedure will be repeated 100 times, so that 100 predictions will be made for each healthy control and 1000 predictions will be made for each autism individual. To carry out the analyses, we will adapt an R script that we previously published the OSF server (https://osf.io/xdnjb/).

Primary outcome variable. The tenfold cross-validation approach with 100 repeats will be performed for each tissue type (gray and white matter) and model type (relevance vector machine, xgboost tree, and xgboost linear). The resulting brain age estimates will be averaged for each tissue and model type. Subsequently, brain age gap will be calculated as the difference between the estimated brain age and the chronological age of the individual. Our primary outcome variable will be the grand mean of brain age gap estimates across all tissue and model types. We will also report results of the gray matter and white matter grand mean.

References

Chen, T., He, T., Benesty, M., Khotilovich, V., Tang, Y., Cho, H., … Li, Y. (2019). xgboost: Extreme Gradient Boosting. Retrieved from https://cran.r-project.org/package=xgboost

Franke, K., Ziegler, G., Klöppel, S., & Gaser, C. (2010). Estimating the age of healthy subjects from T1-weighted MRI scans using kernel methods: Exploring the influence of various parameters. NeuroImage, 50(3), 883–892. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2010.01.005

Qiu, K. (2019). Relevance Vector Machine (RVM). Retrieved from https://github.com/iqiukp/Relevance-Vector-Machine

Tipping, M. E. (2001). Sparse Bayesian Learning and the Relevance Vector Machine. Journal of Machine Learning Research, 1(Jun), 211–244.

Model 1. We will conduct a hierarchical regression analysis to test hypotheses 1a-c. First, we will enter age, age², sex and total intercranial volume (TIV; derived from the cat12 preprocessing) as independent variables and brain age gap as dependent variable into a linear regression model. Then, we will enter diagnosis group (ASD vs. control) as regressor to test if it significantly increases the explained variance in brain age gap (ΔR2). Subsequently, we will enter IQ and, lastly, we will enter the interaction term IQ x diagnosis group into the regression model.

Model 2. To test hypotheses 2a-c, we will carry out an additional hierarchical regression analysis in the ASD group. Again, we will first enter age, age², sex and total intercranial volume as dependent variables and brain age gap as dependent variable. Then, we will test whether symptom severity significantly increases the explained variance when entered as regressor. Next, we will add IQ and, lastly, we will enter the interaction term IQ x symptom severity.

Exploratory Analyses. To test hypotheses 3a-c, we will conduct separate linear regression models with brain age gap serving as dependent variable, sex, age, age2, and TIV serving as covariates, and the respective variable of interest (diagnosis group, IQ, and symptom severity) plus the corresponding interaction term (age x variable of interest) entered as regressors.

q21.value: We will report two-tailed levels of significance and regard associations with p < 0.05 as significant.

registration_responses.q1: Delay or decay? Brain maturation, IQ and symptom severity in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.
registration_responses.q2: Philippe Jawinski, Emily Volbert, Sebastian Markett
registration_responses.q3:
To gain novel insights into structural brain differences and brain maturation in people with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), this study seeks to investigate the biological age of the brain by using the open source datasets ABIDE I and II. We will use structural MRI data and supervised machine learning to estimate each participant’s brain age gap, that is the difference between the brain-predicted age and the chronological age of the individual. A larger brain age gap (indicative for accelerated brain aging) has been shown to be associated with various brain disorders, such as schizophrenia, bipolar spectrum disorders, multiple sclerosis, mild cognitive impairment, and dementia (Kaufmann et al., 2019). Consistently, a growing body of evidence suggests that brain age is linked to physical, cognitive and mental health (Cole, Marioni, Harris, & Deary, 2019; Gaser & Franke, 2019), and may serve as a prospective indicator for Alzheimer’s disease (Franke & Gaser, 2012) as well as mortality (Cole et al., 2018). Due to its involvement in neuropsychiatric and neurodegenerative diseases, brain age also appears to be an encouraging marker for neurodevelopmental disorders such as ASD.

ASD is associated with delays in developmental mile stones, such as delays in the development of motor skills (Provost, Lopez, & Heimerl, 2007) and language (Matson, Mahan, Kozlowski, & Shoemaker, 2010). This may suggest an underlying delay of brain development in individuals with ASD. Furthermore, previous studies have shown a link between ASD and pronounced age-related cortical thinning (Khundrakpam, Lewis, Kostopoulos, Carbonell, & Evans, 2017) and initial increase followed by accelerated decrease in overall brain volume (Courchesne, Campbell, & Solso, 2011; Lange et al., 2015). These findings may suggest that the brain ages prematurely in individuals with ASD. Nevertheless, Kaufman et al. (2019) directly investigated brain age in ASD and reported no significant differences in affected individuals when compared to healthy controls. The authors used data from the open source database ABIDE (http://fcon_1000.projects.nitrc.org/indi/abide/), which provides a variety of MRI and psychometric data for individuals with ASD and healthy controls on a broad age spectrum. Notably, the vast majority of ABIDE participants, including those with ASD, show average or above-average intelligence (Di Martino et al., 2014). This raises the question whether individuals with ASD in the ABIDE dataset rather represent “high functioning ASD”, which may result in only subtle differences in brain morphology when compared to healthy controls. In this case, research on brain ageing in ASD may crucially benefit from taking into account the available information on symptom severity and cognitive functioning.

In keeping with this, previous studies showed that more severe autistic symptoms are also accompanied by more pronounced structural brain aberrations (Chaste et al., 2013; Hazlett et al., 2017; Khundrakpam et al., 2017). Additionally, autistic symptoms typically improve with age, and especially repetitive behaviors can be mostly observed during childhood (Esbensen, Seltzer, Lam, & Bodfish, 2009; Shattuck et al., 2007). Therefore, taking into account symptom severity might be more conclusive when looking at brain maturation in individuals with ASD than solely considering diagnosis status. Consequently, this study aims to investigate if symptom severity is associated with the extent to which brain ageing is altered in individuals with ASD.

Although cognitive impairment is not a symptom of ASD, individuals with ASD often have an intellectual disability. Baio and colleagues (2018) found that among 8-years-old individuals with ASD, 31% had an intellectual disability (IQ ≤ 70) and 25% had an IQ lower than or equal to 85. The combination of ASD and intellectual disability is commonly referred to as “low functioning ASD”. Individuals with ASD and average or above-average IQ are usually more independent in everyday activities and have a higher chance of occupation (Billstedt, Gillberg, & Gillberg, 2011). Although it is unclear how IQ relates to brain age in children and adolescents, in healthy adults, higher cognitive functioning has been associated with lower brain age gap (Poulton, Ramrakha, Caspi, Moffitt, & Ahmad, 2019). On this account, we seek to investigate whether cognitive functioning is associated with brain age in a sample of children, adolescents and adults with and without ASD. In addition, higher levels of general intelligence might be a protective factor in ASD. Thus, we want to examine whether general intelligence may interact with diagnosis status and symptom severity, respectively, in predicting the biological age of the brain. 

While a lower brain age gap has commonly been linked to beneficial health outcomes, this may reasonably not apply to developmental disorders and cognitive functioning in children and adolescents. In an exploratory analysis, we will thus investigate if age moderates the association between brain age gap and each of our variables of interest (diagnosis status, symptom severity, and IQ).


To summarize, this study aims to investigate if diagnosis status, IQ, and diagnosis status x IQ impact the biological age of the brain. Further, we will address whether symptom severity, IQ, and symptom severity x IQ impact on brain age in individuals with ASD. In an exploratory manner, we will further address whether age moderates the associations between brain age and each of our variables of interest (diagnosis group, symptom severity, and IQ).

To carry out the analyses, we will adapt an R script that we previously published the OSF server (https://osf.io/xdnjb/).

Primary outcome variable. The tenfold cross-validation approach with 100 repeats will be performed for each tissue type (gray and white matter) and model type (relevance vector machine, xgboost tree, and xgboost linear). The resulting brain age estimates will be averaged for each tissue and model type. Subsequently, brain age gap will be calculated as the difference between the estimated brain age and the chronological age of the individual. Our primary outcome variable will be the grand mean of brain age gap estimates across all tissue and model types. We will also report results of the gray matter and white matter grand mean.

References

Chen, T., He, T., Benesty, M., Khotilovich, V., Tang, Y., Cho, H., … Li, Y. (2019). xgboost: Extreme Gradient Boosting. Retrieved from https://cran.r-project.org/package=xgboost

Franke, K., Ziegler, G., Klöppel, S., & Gaser, C. (2010). Estimating the age of healthy subjects from T1-weighted MRI scans using kernel methods: Exploring the influence of various parameters. NeuroImage, 50(3), 883–892. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.neuroimage.2010.01.005

Qiu, K. (2019). Relevance Vector Machine (RVM). Retrieved from https://github.com/iqiukp/Relevance-Vector-Machine

Tipping, M. E. (2001). Sparse Bayesian Learning and the Relevance Vector Machine. Journal of Machine Learning Research, 1(Jun), 211–244.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Model 1. We will conduct a hierarchical regression analysis to test hypotheses 1a-c. First, we will enter age, age², sex and total intercranial volume (TIV; derived from the cat12 preprocessing) as independent variables and brain age gap as dependent variable into a linear regression model. Then, we will enter diagnosis group (ASD vs. control) as regressor to test if it significantly increases the explained variance in brain age gap (ΔR2). Subsequently, we will enter IQ and, lastly, we will enter the interaction term IQ x diagnosis group into the regression model.

Model 2. To test hypotheses 2a-c, we will carry out an additional hierarchical regression analysis in the ASD group. Again, we will first enter age, age², sex and total intercranial volume as dependent variables and brain age gap as dependent variable. Then, we will test whether symptom severity significantly increases the explained variance when entered as regressor. Next, we will add IQ and, lastly, we will enter the interaction term IQ x symptom severity.

Exploratory Analyses. To test hypotheses 3a-c, we will conduct separate linear regression models with brain age gap serving as dependent variable, sex, age, age2, and TIV serving as covariates, and the respective variable of interest (diagnosis group, IQ, and symptom severity) plus the corresponding interaction term (age x variable of interest) entered as regressors.

attributes.title: The effect of social anxiety on the persistence of avoidance after threat extinction

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: The sample size has been estimated based upon power analyses using repeated measures ANCOVA. The sample size of this study is based on a power analysis using the effect size n2 = 0.22, from a previous experiment that reported the main effect of CS for SCR during extinction after avoidance learning (Vervliet & Indeken, 2015). The following parameters were used: effect size f = 0.53 (converted from n2 = 0.22), α error probability = 0.01, Power (1-β error probability) = 0.95, number of groups = 2 (CS+,  CS-), numerator df = 2, number of covariates = 4 (SPIN, BFNES, IU, Trait Anxiety). The total sample size suggested is n = 87.

analyses.value:
To examine the main hypotheses outlined in the previous section we will carry out the following analyses:

(1) To examine whether participants exhibit greater levels of conditioned responding towards the CS+ compared to the CS- during threat acquisition, a paired samples t-test will be carried out with SCR magnitude during CS+ and CS- trials. This analysis will be repeated but for ratings of expectancy towards the CS+ and CS-. 
(2) To determine whether high social anxiety is associated with increased avoidance behaviour during avoidance learning, a repeated measures ANCOVA will be carried out with avoidant button presses towards the CS (CS+ vs CS-) added as a within subject factor and SPIN, IU and trait anxiety scores added as continuous predictor variables. Avoidant responses will be scored as 1 (vs 0) and will be averaged per participant, per CS prior to statistical analysis. 
(3) To establish whether individual differences in trait social anxiety affect SCR magnitude during extinction learning, a 2 X 2 repeated measures ANCOVA (CS (CS+ vs CS-) x Time (early extinction learning vs late extinction learning) will be carried out with SPIN, IU and trait anxiety scores added as continuous predictor variables. 
(4) To examine whether the return of the opportunity to avoid the CS after extinction learning results in participants with high levels of social anxiety reverting to avoidant behaviour to a greater extent than participants with low levels of social anxiety, a repeated measures ANCOVA will be conducted with avoidant button presses towards the CS (CS+ vs CS-) during the avoidance test phase added to the model as a within subject factor and SPIN, IU and trait anxiety scores added as continuous predictor variables. Avoidant responses will be scored as 1 (vs 0) and will be averaged per participant, per CS prior to statistical analysis.
(5) To investigate whether the return of the availability of avoidance after extinction learning results in the recovery of the conditioned response during a re-extinction phase in high socially anxious participants, a repeated measures ANCOVA will be conducted with SCR towards the CS (CS+ vs CS-) added to the model as a within subject factor with SPIN, IU and trait anxiety scores added as continuous predictor variables. 

         Where a significant interaction is observed with social anxiety in the above analyses, we will perform follow-up pairwise comparisons on the estimated marginal means of the relevant conditions estimated at specific social anxiety values of + or – 1 SD of the mean SPIN score. Similar analyses have been published elsewhere (Morriss, Macdonald, & van Reekum, 2016; Morriss, McSorley, & van Reekum, 2017). Further, In case of high collinearity possibly resulting in a null effect and to check for consistency of conclusions, we will ascertain whether social anxiety by itself is associated with these effects by repeating all ANCOVAs reported above with only the SPIN added to the model as a continuous predictor variable.

Exploratory Analysis – As above, any significant effects associated with IU or trait anxiety will be followed up with pairwise comparisons on the estimated marginal means of the relevant conditions estimated at specific IU/trait value of + or – 1 SD of the mean IU/trait score. We will also examine whether higher social anxiety is associated with increased ratings of expectancy towards the CS+ throughout the task. We will conduct a 2 X 7 repeated measures ANCOVA with CS (CS+ vs CS-) and Time (mid acquisition, post acquisition, post avoidance learning, mid extinction, post extinction, post avoidance test, post re-extinction) as within subject factors and SPIN, IU and trait anxiety scores added as continuous predictor variables. Further, to examine the consistency of findings between self-report measures of social anxiety, we will repeat all analyses replacing SPIN scores with scores from the Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale (BFNES).

outliers.value:
Checks for outliers will not be performed for trait, IU and social anxiety scores. This is based on the premise that any identified outliers might reflect true variation in levels of anxiety or intolerance of uncertainty. This is also true for avoidance behaviour and US expectancy ratings. 

We will check for outliers in our SCR data and will exclude any participant that displays a CS+ vs CS- difference score of + or – 3 SD from the group mean. 

Once data collection is complete, we will identify non-learners (individuals who do not learn the association between the CS+ and US) and non-responders (individuals who do not demonstrate a SCR in trials that do not include the US). We will first run the analyses including these participants and then again with these participants excluded. If excluding such participants does not change the pattern or significance of the results of SCR, for reasons of completeness we will include non-learners and non-responders in our analysis. If excluding such individuals alters the pattern or significance of SCR findings, non-learners and non-responders will be omitted from the analysis.

dependent.value: We will measure skin conductance responses, expectancy ratings and avoidant behaviour during an associative threat learning and avoidance task. To assess social anxiety, intolerance of uncertainty and trait anxiety, we will administer the Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN) (Connor, Davidson, Churchill, Sherwood, Foa, & Weisler), The Brief Fear of Negative Evaluation Scale (BFNES)(Carleton, McCreary, Norton, & Asmundson, 2006), The Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale (IUS) (Freeton, Rhéaume, Letarte, Dugas, & Ladouceur, 1994) and the trait version of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (Spielberger, Gorsuch, Lushene, Vagg & Jacobs, 1968).

conditions.value:
The experimental task will include five phases; threat acquisition, avoidance learning, response prevention and extinction learning, avoidance test, and re-extinction. All participants will complete all five phases. During threat acquisition, participants will be presented with images of the neutral facial expressions of two separate female identities (CS), appearing on the screen one at a time. The neutral expression of one of these individuals (CS+) will be paired with a loud female voice shouting “Get lost” and an electric shock (US) to the little finger during 50% of CS+ trials (i.e. a partial reinforcement schedule). The 50% pairing rate is designed to maximise the unpredictability of the CS+/US contingency. The other neutral face (CS-) will never be paired with the US or any other stimulus. During the avoidance learning phase, the CS+ and CS- will be presented in the same manner as during threat acquisition, however, participants will be given the opportunity to avoid the US on any given trial by pressing the space bar. If the participant chooses not to avoid they will always receive the US during CS+ trials, however, the US will never be presented during CS- trials, regardless of avoidant behaviour. If the participant chooses to avoid, the US will not be presented during that trial. The response prevention and extinction learning phase will then take place during which participants will be presented with the CS+ and CS- but with no opportunity to avoid and no reinforcement of the US. Next, in order to assess the persistence of avoidance responding, the opportunity to avoid will be returned within the avoidance test phase. During the avoidance test phase the US will never be presented. During a final re-extinction phase, the opportunity to avoid will again be removed in order to measure the persistence of threat extinction following renewed avoidance availability. 

Conditioning contingencies will be counterbalanced across participants with half of participants receiving identity A paired with the US and the other half of participants receiving identity B paired with the US.

hypothesis.value:
In this experiment, we primarily seek to examine the effects of social anxiety on the persistence of avoidance after threat extinction. 

 We have several hypotheses: 
(1) During threat acquisition, all participants regardless of their level of social anxiety will exhibit greater levels of conditioned responding, indexed by larger skin conductance response (SCR) magnitudes and higher expectancy ratings, towards a learned threat (CS+) versus safety (CS-) cue. 
(2) During an avoidance learning phase, we expect high levels of social anxiety to be associated with increased avoidance of both learned threat (CS+) and safety (CS-) cues, indicated by a button press. 
(3) The extinction learning phase will be split into ‘early’ and ‘late’ phases (i.e. first 8 CS+ and CS- trials vs last 8 CS+ and CS- trials). We expect that during early threat extinction all participants, regardless of level of social anxiety, will demonstrate a significantly larger SCR towards the CS+ compared to the CS-. Also, we expect all participants to demonstrate successful threat extinction as demonstrated by a lack of differential SCR between the CS+ and CS-, during the late part of the extinction learning phase. 
(4) Following a threat extinction phase, we predict that high social anxiety will be associated with a stronger return of avoidant behaviour towards both threat (CS+) and safety cues (CS-) during an avoidance test phase.
(5) The return of the availability of avoidance after threat extinction will result in the recovery of the conditioned response, as demonstrated by an elevated SCR to the CS+ compared to the CS-, in individuals exhibiting higher relative to lower levels of social anxiety. 

We will test the specificity of social anxiety effects, as measured by the Social Phobia Inventory (SPIN), by controlling for trait anxiety and intolerance of uncertainty (IU), both of which have been associated with deficits in safety learning within previous work (Morriss, Christakou, & Van Reekum, 2015, 2016; Morriss & van Reekum, 2019, Sehlmeyer et al., 2011).
